text: :desktop_computer:  Anyone recently migrate their website or blog from WP to headless WP/gatsby, contentful, ghost, or webflow? How did it affect your rankings and traffic? Content workflows?

elements.text: Anyone recently migrate their website or blog from WP to headless WP/gatsby, contentful, ghost, or webflow? How did it affect your rankings and traffic? Content workflows?

text: Some dev friends swear by webflow, others say that moving away from classic WP (even over to gatsby with WP CMS) will slow down our workflows and stall our organic growth. I'd love for this group to chime in. :heart:

elements.text: Some dev friends swear by webflow, others say that moving away from classic WP (even over to gatsby with WP CMS) will slow down our workflows and stall our organic growth. I'd love for this group to chime in.

text: So far I've only managed to GIVE backlinks through HARO (in exchange for some sweet expert quotes). Soooo, not the backlink opportunity I was hoping for. I still reply to a query every now and then.

root.text: :desktop_computer:  Anyone recently migrate their website or blog from WP to headless WP/gatsby, contentful, ghost, or webflow? How did it affect your rankings and traffic? Content workflows?

elements.text: Anyone recently migrate their website or blog from WP to headless WP/gatsby, contentful, ghost, or webflow? How did it affect your rankings and traffic? Content workflows?
I use webflow - no problems in traffic yet.

text: <@UJ32V555H>  looks great! what platform do you use for the primary domain/marketing site?

elements.text: looks great! what platform do you use for the primary domain/marketing site?

text: <@UN29JC48H> We just migrated to the same set up that <@UJ32V555H> mentioned. We combined our marketing site (php) with our blog (WP) so that they are all housed in one space. The speed is great and we built reusable components in WP so I can enter content/build pages now. We did add a layer to content publishing that wasn't there before. I used to push posts straight to prod but now I push to staging and our dev pushes them to prod. It can be a little slower if there's anything blocking the pipeline, but it's awesome to have everything go through QA automation.

elements.text: We just migrated to the same set up that

mentioned. We combined our marketing site (php) with our blog (WP) so that they are all housed in one space. The speed is great and we built reusable components in WP so I can enter content/build pages now. We did add a layer to content publishing that wasn't there before. I used to push posts straight to prod but now I push to staging and our dev pushes them to prod. It can be a little slower if there's anything blocking the pipeline, but it's awesome to have everything go through QA automation.

text: <@UN29JC48H> Primary domain is webflow. Love using webflow, but it’s not quite there from a CMS perspective to run a blog off of in my opinion. I wanted something that was able to tie in with all the plugins I was used to using.

elements.text: Primary domain is webflow. Love using webflow, but it’s not quite there from a CMS perspective to run a blog off of in my opinion. I wanted something that was able to tie in with all the plugins I was used to using.

text: <@UMX8MPHA6> the event used Intrado, it was pretty limiting. Not a lot of options. The most “unique” thing we did was try to encourage people to go into a live Zoom meeting room to chat with a real human. We had a few people pop in, but not many.

elements.text: the event used Intrado, it was pretty limiting. Not a lot of options. The most “unique” thing we did was try to encourage people to go into a live Zoom meeting room to chat with a real human. We had a few people pop in, but not many.

text: Yeah I manage event marketing for my company and the pivot to virtual conferences has been a tough one. We’ve tried doing “fun” things like hosting a networking happy hour and it’s a huge challenge getting people to engage on a personal level when the reality is that you’re coming on webcam with random people drink in hand - not exactly the most fun experience :disappointed:

elements.text: Yeah I manage event marketing for my company and the pivot to virtual conferences has been a tough one. We’ve tried doing “fun” things like hosting a networking happy hour and it’s a huge challenge getting people to engage on a personal level when the reality is that you’re coming on webcam with random people drink in hand - not exactly the most fun experience

text: Totally! I think it’s going to take time before people feel ready to truly “engage” virtually.

elements.text: Totally! I think it’s going to take time before people feel ready to truly “engage” virtually.

text:
:wave:  Hey everyone! I’m looking for advice for distributing content internally to sales and customer success teams so that they have the relevant resources on hand when talking to prospects + customers.

Our content team produces quite a lot - 2 blogs a week + podcast + webinar + weekly activity idea sheets (we’re a child care app company). We currently have a content-updates channel where we post as things are published but not everyone in the company pays attention to that. Any advice is welcome!

elements.text:
Hey everyone! I’m looking for advice for distributing content internally to sales and customer success teams so that they have the relevant resources on hand when talking to prospects + customers.

Our content team produces quite a lot - 2 blogs a week + podcast + webinar + weekly activity idea sheets (we’re a child care app company). We currently have a content-updates channel where we post as things are published but not everyone in the company pays attention to that. Any advice is welcome!

text: An easy way is to send a weekly newsletter to the sales/CS group emails with all the relevant content that you think they'll need. These folks generally read emails diligently!

elements.text: An easy way is to send a weekly newsletter to the sales/CS group emails with all the relevant content that you think they'll need. These folks generally read emails diligently!

text: Less an answer but more of a framework: I’ve heard it described that sales people are “hunters” (short-term motivated) while other roles, like content, are “farmers” (long-term motivated). To marry the two working styles, one has to insert content assets in the sales person’s normal workflow. Seriously, they can’t spend more than 5 extra minutes doing anything outside of their normal tasks because that’s taking money out of their pocket. So maybe its attending their standup and letting them know? Auto pinging them in Slack or a CRM when something is published?

elements.text: Less an answer but more of a framework: I’ve heard it described that sales people are “hunters” (short-term motivated) while other roles, like content, are “farmers” (long-term motivated). To marry the two working styles, one has to insert content assets in the sales person’s normal workflow. Seriously, they can’t spend more than 5 extra minutes doing anything outside of their normal tasks because that’s taking money out of their pocket. So maybe its attending their standup and letting them know? Auto pinging them in Slack or a CRM when something is published?

text: I agree with <@U012GHRAHDK> on the newsletter. And actually, you can set that up so you know if Sales is actually opening it. And if they’re not, over time, then maybe it’s time for plan B. And as <@UJE5LQ2JC> suggests, grabbing five minutes in they’re standup is also a great idea. Maybe the best way to grab the attention of Sales.

elements.text: I agree with
on the newsletter. And actually, you can set that up so you know if Sales is actually opening it. And if they’re not, over time, then maybe it’s time for plan B. And as
suggests, grabbing five minutes in they’re standup is also a great idea. Maybe the best way to grab the attention of Sales.

text: If you're a B2B SaaS content marketer who also tracks SEO performance, what's a good CTR from organic search for your site overall? I've heard 2-3% is average, but curious to hear what you all see.

elements.text: If you're a B2B SaaS content marketer who also tracks SEO performance, what's a good CTR from organic search for your site overall? I've heard 2-3% is average, but curious to hear what you all see.

text: I’m in B2B professional services and ours is 2.4% overall.  We haven’t focused on SEO in a while but I’d say 2-3 sounds about right but with some focus you could bump that up.

elements.text: I’m in B2B professional services and ours is 2.4% overall.  We haven’t focused on SEO in a while but I’d say 2-3 sounds about right but with some focus you could bump that up.

text: That’s about right. B2B SaaS site, ours is 3-4%

elements.text: That’s about right. B2B SaaS site, ours is 3-4%

text: Hmmmm, sitewide? As long as you're publishing consistently, it won't change but if you change in cadence the new ranking content will through your numbers off. I almost never (ever) look at sitewide metrics for CTR but tend to dig most down to a page-level.

elements.text: Hmmmm, sitewide? As long as you're publishing consistently, it won't change but if you change in cadence the new ranking content will through your numbers off. I almost never (ever) look at sitewide metrics for CTR but tend to dig most down to a page-level.
